title: Wednesday, 6th March 2019

BE11:08am

The head of the US Food and Drug Administration plans to step down next month, after two years in which he pushed for lower drug prices and locked horns with the tobacco industry over ecigarettes.

Scott Gottlieb led the FDA as it tackled problems including teenage vaping and opioid abuse. As commissioner, he made plans to try to rein in the rising cost of prescription drugs, speeding up the approvals of generic drugs.

BE11:09am

He wants to spend more time with his family.

11:09 am
BE11:09am

Dr Gottlieb, a cancer survivor and physician, laid down plans in the autumn for sweeping measures to curb what he called a “disturbing” trend for young people to become addicted to nicotine. They included a planned ban on menthol cigarettes and flavoured cigars, as well as restrictions on the availability of flavoured ecigarettes to locations off limits to anyone under 21.

His exit from the FDA would be seen as “positive” for the tobacco industry, said Bonnie Herzog, analyst at Wells Fargo, although it would “introduce some uncertainty”. She questioned whether the FDA would now follow through in enforcing some of the restrictions being implemented under Dr Gottlieb.

BE11:09am

Which, yes, okay.

A. M. Pushed out by the donald?
BE11:09am

But it's hardly his personal vendetta against the tobacco industry, is it?

JimboRock Good morning, Any comment on Baillie Gifford's Anderson regarding Tesla
DJ morning

There's a fair bit of evidence that smoking causes cancer. The FDA's very existence is intertwined with tobacco research and (eventually) legislation.

cloudy In the old days they said smoking was good for you.

BE11:15am

We think Dr. Gottlieb’s resignation takes the risk of a menthol cig ban off the table until a new FDA commissioner is appointed. The idea of menthol ban isn’t new. David Kessler, the FDA commissioner in the early 1990s, had also argued for a menthol ban. There are high procedural hurdles to get a menthol cig ban rule in place, which will then inevitably face a challenge from the industry. Any new FDA commissioner has to be willing to take on the battle, over and above the various other demands on his/her time, such as lowering the cost of the US healthcare system.

· BAT’s stock was trading at GBP35 before the menthol ban announcement, IMB at GBP27 and MO at 65. Trading at 9x 2019E P/E for BAT and IMB, and 12x for MO, the stocks can easily see a 20% bounce from here, in our view.

· Any new FDA commissioner has to tackle the alarming rise in e-cigs youth use. We think that the flavor bans on e-cigs and flavored cigars are still very likely. These are deemed products and need to go through their pre-market tobacco approval (PMTA) or substantial equivalence (SE) process by August 2021 (cigars) or August 2022 (e-cigs). The FDA has much higher discretion on flavor bans on e-cigs or cigars than it has for cigs (which are grandfathered products and need an extensive rulemaking process).

· Since June last year, we have maintained a very consistent view – US nicotine gross profit growth has accelerated due to e-cigs, and ultimately a rising tide lifts all boats. Altria’s forecasts on JUUL suggest our thesis is in the right direction. Lessening regulatory risks are likely to now likely to bring this new US nicotine normal to the fore.

Kiwi-juice Does anyone know the company CityChamps Watch and Jewellery Swiss co? A sort of mini Anbang / Fosun? It has no bad press. HK Ticker is 256. Trying to understand how solid they are
Excel Developer The problem with anti-government politicians is that when they get into government they are just useless at it because they ain't motivated. Chris Grayling is the best example, but Boris was rubbish, Iain Duncan Smith was a poor administrator (see universal credit), Liam "42 trade deals by Brexit" Fox is another example.

Tweets from Trump (please don't make me look at those) suggest Gottlieb left of his own accord so the most we can argue here is that there might be a vacuum at the top for a bit.

11:16 am
BE11:17am

Jefferies incoming:

A. M. @Kiwi-juice: it's neither here nor there, but the name doesn't really inspire confidence, does it?
BE11:17am

After announcing in November certain flavours of e-cigarettes were to be removed from retail stores to be sold only online, while this action has already been taken by Juul (Altria have removed all e-cigarettes), BAT and Imperial have still been selling flavours until further guidance was given by the FDA. If this leads to a delay in this guidance then it could prove to be advantageous to both BAT and Imperial with regards to potentially claiming market share back from Juul.

BE11:18am

Another area it could lead to a delay is approval of PMTAs and MRTPs. Potentially most impactful in this respect could be a delay to IQOS approval. This would be a negative for Altria and PM, but a positive for BAT (it already has a heated product approved). On the negative side for BAT, it could potentially lead to a delay of MRTP on Camel snus. Also potentially seeing support could be Swedish Match if a flavoured cigar ban is delayed but we think moving ahead with this is much more simple and straightforward than other actions, meaning a near term announcement could still be very likely.

Below that the numbers are pretty mixed rather than outright bad. Here's Panmure.

BE11:26am

L&G has reported FY18 results in which operating profit was broadly in-line with consensus. Key highlights from the results were: 1) Headline operating profit of £2,335m compared to consensus at £2,273m and our £2,331m forecast helped by a greater than anticipated mortality reserve release of £433m (cons £376m); 2) DPS of 16.42p which was bang in line with consensus 3) SII coverage ratio was 6% lower than consensus at 188%. 4) Net release at £1440m (-1%) was lower than anticipated reflecting an unusually high new business surplus last year that was not repeated this year. The stock is currently trading on 9.1x 2019E Op EPS and with a 6.1% dividend yield. We see the dividend as being supported by a combination of strong balance sheet, cash generation and potential further mortality releases. We re-iterate our Buy rating and maintain our view that the shares are undervalued.

11:26 am
BE11:27am

Management guiding towards solvency coming back to circa 190% at March 4.

BE11:27am

BE11:27am

L&G's H2'18 operating results from divisions (ex. mortality releases) and EPS (ex. mortality releases) where roughly in line with consensus. The quality
of the results will be debated as the net release from operation missed by 13% bu
this was made up for by routine mortality assumption changes (different from mortality releases). The net release from operations miss was due to lower new business surplus in LGR driven by 1) lower margins accepted on some of the larger H2 bulk annuity plans and 2) greater volumes of higher strain US business that was contained within the record £10bn of 2018 annuity sales. The bulk annuity pipeline remains robust at £20bn but the margin outlook will be key going forward.

Just Eat's prelims were largely as expected following the January trading update and FY19E guidance remains unchanged. Canadian SkipTheDishes (STD) was the stand-out performer with revenue +186% to £180m; it should break into profit in FY19. This is encouraging as the STD model is being rolled into the UK and Australia and will be key to JE's ability to tap into the Quick Service Restaurant (QSR) market. JE has confirmed that it will participate in funding iFood's growth plans to maintain its shareholding. Just Eat's share price is up 36% YTD and has recovered 60% of last year's decline, helped in no small part by activist Cat Rock's megaphone diplomacy.

We expect the market to focus on the call today. The company pre-released
2018 results and 2019 guidance on 21 January, so there are few surprises there.
The key incremental data today is the decision on iFood and geographic
breakdowns.
(i) UK … 4Q UK Order growth of 13% (33.2m) is below MSe of 33.8m, +16% (Css.
34.1m, +16%). UK revenue was up 27% to £386m (Mse £392m) and underlying
EBITDA increased 22% to £189.5m (Mse £180m). Just Eat invested £21m into the
rollout of delivery, slightly more than the £20m planned investment. The
company has seen "improving trend in the delivery economics reaching breakeven
on a gross profit basis in more mature zones."
(ii) Australia ...revenue growth was flat (£47m), slightly better than our forecast
for -3%.
(iii) Canada … revenue was up 186% to £178m (Mse £169m) and the segment
reached breakeven in Q4.
(iv) Brazil..."Just Eat will fully participate in funding iFood's exciting growth plans,
maintaining its shareholding" which we think will be taken well by the market
given the attractiveness of the business.

BE11:38am

Prereported: Just Eat's revenue of £780m (+43%) and EBITDA of £174m (margin
22%) are broadly in-line with consensus/Mse of £779m and EBITDA of £172m,
respectively.
FY 2019 guidance. On January 21st, the company provided guidance for 2019.
Revenues are expected to be between £1-1.1bn, while EBITDA is expected to be in
the range of £185-205m. At the midpoint this is in-line on 2019 consensus
revenue but 9% below on EBITDA. We are in-line on revenue, but 2% ahead on
EBITDA. The shares are trading on 4.2x EV/20e Sales. We are overweight.

11:40 am
BE11:40am

Industry update. Highlighting a few key movements in the delivery market:
 Deliveroo announced ‘click and collect’, allowing consumers to order
online and to pick it up themselves. This will likely boost Deliveroo’s
margin and cash flow potential, as well as expanding consumer choice.
 10,000+ companies have now signed up for Deliveroo for Business in 14
markets worldwide, providing Deliveroo with larger pocketed customers,
such as employers. We use it at Peel Hunt when working late.
 Uber Eats will cut its fees from 35% to 30% and enters the marketplace
model with a fee of 13%. Competition for Just Eat (14%) and Deliveroo,
which launched marketplace last year. Could cause pricing pressure.
 Could the Lyft IPO imply that Uber is coming to the market? With cash
raised, it could acquire Just Eat, solving a lot of issues. Just Eat: delivery
through a larger entity. Uber Eats: enter marketplace model much faster.

This reduces our FY19 forecast net debt/EBITDA from c.2.9x to 2.6x which will fall to 2.4x at April 2020 end. Note we include working capital finance in our net debt calculation.

Tom Dalgleish According to Webb's filter
BE11:51am

In addition to the disposal, management has released a brief trading update for the period since November 1. Trading is in line with management expectations with volume growth reported as good, surprisingly pointing to a limited slowdown in volume growth as reported by the wider sector. The US continues to perform well. Group margins are expected to progress further in H219. The outlook is reasonably confident while noting that macroeconomic conditions remain uncertain. We expect this release will be well received by the market today as the company makes progress in reducing its elevated leverage and the trading update does not allude to the slowdown seen in sector volumes into calendar Q418. We expect to see more disposals over the next twelve months as the company charts a course back to acquisition growth. Nonetheless we maintain our view that there is material underlying downside to forecasts in FY20 and note we downgraded Smurfit Kappa by EBITDA forecasts 5-10% last week. We remain cautious on the sector.

undefined
11:51 am
BE11:51am

Well, that was brief.

BE11:52am

Aon confirms it is not pursuing business combination with Willis Towers Watson

Canada NewsWire

LONDON, March 6, 2019

LONDON, March 6, 2019 CNW -- Aon plc (NYSE: AON) today issued the following statement:

Consistent with Aon's stated focus on return on invested capital the firm regularly evaluates a variety of potential opportunities within and adjacent to its industry. Aon had considered such a possibility with regard to Willis Towers Watson. News of that consideration subsequently became public and Aon was required to issue a statement because Willis Towers Watson is an Irish company and is subject to Irish regulatory requirements. As a result of media speculation, those regulations required Aon to make the disclosure at a very early stage in the consideration of a potential all-share business combination. Aon today confirms that it does not intend to pursue this business combination.

By Ed Hammond and Matthew Monks
(Bloomberg) -- Aon Plc is considering an offer to buy rival insurance brokerage Willis Towers Watson Plc, according to people familiar with the matter, in what could be the industry’s largest merger on record. Willis Towers shares soared. Aon is preparing to submit a bid for Willis Towers in the coming weeks, said the people, who asked to not be identified because the matter isn’t public. The companies have held preliminary talks, the people said. No final decision has been made and Aon could opt to not move forward with an offer, they said.

11:57 am
IWG Plc (IWG:LSE): Last: 232.80, up 1.2 (+0.52%), High: 235.80, Low: 220.30, Volume: 995.57k
BE11:58am

But the IFRS16 guidance is probably the incrementally interesting bit of it. Needless to say, it has quite an effect on a company whose entire schtick is leaseholds.

BE11:59am

RBC can summarise the headlines.

11:59 am
BE11:59am

FY Results and Details
Sales - £2,535m vs forecast £2,530m

EBIT - £154.1m vs forecast £151.1m (cons £153.3m)

EPS – 11.6p vs forecast 11.9p (cons 12.1p)

DPS – 6.3p vs forecast 6.3p (cons 6.2p) – FY up 11%

Sales

FY revenues up 9.7% Mature CC growth at 4.6% vs 2.4% in H1 and 3.9% in Q3, although closures at 3%
This suggests an acceleration to 8.2% in Q4
Mature occupancy at 74.2% vs 74.3% in Q3 and 73.8% at H1
Franchising momentum is increasing, adding 49 locations (135 in total)
Margin

Gross margin at 16.1% vs 16.4% expected
SG&A 10.0% sales vs 10.4% forecast and vs 10.1% last year
Overall EBIT margin at 6.1% vs 6.0% forecast, down 90bp
Cashflow

299 locations opened for capex of £332m (vs guidance of £275m and £230m)
Net debt at £460.8m (vs forecast £420m and vs £434m at Q3) reflecting the high capex
Outlook – Expect FY19 trading in line with expectations.

Valuation – The stock trades on a 19E PE 16x, EV/EBITA 14.5x - a significant premium to other cyclicals in the sector.

BE11:59am

Spinning down to the accounting stuff .....

BE11:59am

There is no impact to cashflow, but £6.2bn of leases go onto the balance sheet and because IFRS16 front loads costs and IWG’s lease portfolio is young (c.3.5 years), there is an exaggerated impact on EPS. As a result, 2018 basic EPS of 11.7p would be 7.0p, or 40% lower under IFRS16. This is clearly unhelpful and likely to be confusing, despite having no impact on the economics of the business. As such, we believe the market will continue to value the business on cash – with the caveat that a/ it is cyclical and b/ IWG is likely to carry on expanding aggressively through the capex line.

GBKrona @CS1 - no, but his wife must be planning it and hoping ....
12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

Does it matter, tho? Yes. Yes it does. Peel Hunt:

BE12:00pm

We fully accept that fundamental cash flow is not affected, but when you move net debt/EBITDA from 1.2x to 4.8x and reduce EPS by 40% for an accounting charge, investors cannot simply ignore it. Even though the size of the change is broadly in line with expectations, coupled with an underlying PBT downgrade today, we see the shares as unlikely to perform. Our TP reduces to 190p from 220p.

BE12:01pm

That's a common theme we're seeing on the IFRS 16 stuff right now. Spire, Rolls-Royce, etc.

12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

No cashflow impact but, really, you can't expect a rerating when your net debt's just quadrupled.

BE12:02pm

Peel Hunt also takes forecasts back for good measure.

BE12:02pm

With a weakening macro, continuing investment and active competition, we are revising down FY19E PBT/EPS, which do not yet incorporate IFRS16, and FY20E of £175.1m/15.1p and £200.8m/17.4p, respectively to £155m/13.4p and £176m/15.2p calculated on the historical basis. On the new basis, EPS probably falls to closer to 8p in FY19E and 9p in FY20E (corrects an earlier Spark comment), but these are highly provisional numbers. We are reducing our TP to 190p (from 220p), 24x revised FY19E, 14x pre IFRS16 FY19E. Hold.

Bluesky21 IWG net debt is going up because of how much money they are spending
12:02 pm
undefined
Bluesky21 Net debt up £165m to fund dividend (£94m) and "growth" CapEx (£332m)
Pharma #IFRS16 Ny non-expert take on this was that the new regulations provide a better picture of company finances, by stopping companies from hiding liabilities off balance sheet.Can any ROTR accountants comment on whether that is a reasonable summary?
Bluesky21 It's an impressive stance to take in the face of WeWork

After a disappointing performance in recent years, Lufthansa targets operating margins for Eurowings similar to the levels seen at easyJet. easyJet poses significant direct competition for SWISS in Geneva and indirect competition in Zurich due to the airline’s strong network at Basel Airport. After the acquisition of Air Berlin’s assets at Berlin Tegel Airport, easyJet is now the main carrier in Berlin, where we expect both easyJet and Eurowings to generate losses this year. While easyJet’s service massively overlaps with IAG and AF-KLM, we believe Lufthansa’s and easyJet’s joint businesses would imply manageable hurdles with the EU competition authorities.

BE12:07pm

We estimate that the integration of easyJet into
Lufthansa’s network could generate synergies worth c. EUR300m a year in the short term, as well as additional benefits in terms of easyJet feeding transfer traffic to Lufthansa’s airplanes, particularly (but not only) from Italy, and a more optimal use of slots at Paris Orly Airport longer term. Lufthansa’s and easyJet’s fleets are compatible. We think that easyJet currently trades largely in line with the value of its owned fleet, which we estimate at 1,200p. We would not be surprised if Lufthansa were to make an offer for easyJet over the coming months, particularly in the event that easyJet were to come under further pressure due to Brexit. The integration of easyJet into the group could result in the Lufthansa group being valued based on a sum-of-the-parts model, crystallising the value of the maintenance, repair & overhaul (MRO), and catering divisions.
